doc.field: Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
Hand I is responsible for all the scene notations in the Smock Alley PB. No scene notations in Folger F2 PB.
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
I.i (opening) Presence (Bell, 'SCENE the Palace'; Kemble, 'A Room in Duke Orsino's Palace' [reverses scenes i and ii]).
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
I.ii (opening) Towne (Bell, 'SCENE the street'; Kemble,' The Seacoast').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
I.iii (opening) Court (Bell, 'SCENE Olivia's house'; Kemble, 'A Room in Olivia's House').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
I.iv (opening) Court (thus continuing the setting; Bell, 'SCENE the palace'; Kemble, 'A Room in Duke Orsino's Palace').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
I.v (opening) setting continued (Bell, 'SCENE Olivia's house'; Kemble, 'A Room in Olivia's House').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
II.i (opening) Towne (Bell, 'SCENE the street'; Kemble, 'A Seaport').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
II.ii (opening) Court (Bell, setting continued; Kemble, 'A Street before Olivia's House' [reverses scenes II.i and II.ii]).
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
II.iii (opening) setting continued (Bell, 'SCENE Olivia's house'; Kemble, 'A Dining-room in Olivia's House').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
II.iv (opening) setting continued (Bell, 'SCENE The palace'; Kemble, 'A Hall in Duke Orsino's Palace').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
II.v (opening) setting continued (Bell, Kemble, 'SCENE Olivia's garden').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
III.i (opening) Court (thus continuing the setting; Bell, Kemble, as in II.v [Kemble places III.iii after III i]).
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
III.ii (opening) setting continued (Bell, 'SCENE Olivia's house'; Kemble, 'A Room in Olivia's House').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
III.iii (opening) scene setting lost because of tear in PB (Bell, 'SCENE the street'; Kemble, 'A public Square' [Kemble places III.iii before III.ii]).
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
III.iv (opening) Court (Bell, 'SCENE Olivia's house'; Kemble, 'A Room in Olivia's House'; Bell, Kemble begin a new scene at III.iv.301).
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
IV.i (opening) Town (Bell, 'SCENE the street'; Kemble, 'The Street before Olivia's House').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
IV.ii (opening) Court (Bell, 'SCENE Olivia's house'; Kemble, 'A Gallery in Olivia's House').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
IV.iii (opening) setting continued (Bell, 'SCENE a street'; Kemble, 'Olivia's Garden').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
V.i (opening) Court (thus continuing the setting; Bell, 'SCENE a cut wood'; Kemble, 'The Street before Olivia's House').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
In the Smock Alley PB all cuts were probably made by Hand I.
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
I.ii I.ii.62 Be you . . . be,] Underlined, most probably for deletion (Bell, Kemble retain, but Kemble substitutes 'page' for F 'Eunuch').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8

II.iv II.iv.5-6 More then . . . times.] Circled (Bell, Kemble cut 1-14). 87 Tell her . . . fortune:] Circled (F reads 'told' for Ff 1-2 'hold', making nonsense of the line; Hand II corrects to 'hold').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
III.i 52-54 I am . . . chin.] Circled (Bell, Kemble cut 53-54 ['though . . . chin.'], Hand I making the same cut originally, then including 'I am . . . one,').
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
III.iv 290-292 Nothing of . . . velour.] Partly circled, probably for deletion.
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
In the Folger F2 PB all cuts were probably made by Hand I.
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8

II.iii 39-47An. I, I. I . . . good.] Short angled lines through speech-prefixes at 39 and 47 suggest a possible cut (Bell cuts 31-59 ['Now a . . . contagion.']; Kemble cuts 32-60 ['there is . . . indeed?']). 115-121To. But I . . . not.] Between heavy horizontal lines, 117 partly underlined (Bell, Kemble cut 118-121 and read, respectively, F 'Out o'tune sir, ye lye' [122] as 'Sir, you lie:' and 'You lie.', an adjustment required by Hand I's cut, but not made).
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8

IV.ii 13-23 Clo. Bonos dies . . . Knave.] Heavy slanted vertical stroke through these lines, probably for deletion. 133-141 In a trice . . . Divell.] Between crisscrossed horizontal lines (so Bell, Kemble; see Textual changes, IV.ii.132).
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8

In the Smock Alley PB Hand I makes only one certainly identifiable textual change: IV.ii.32 thus wronged] thus usd (F reading heavily blotted). There are a number of heavy blots obscuring the F text, but only in this instance does Hand I make any attempt to bridge the gap in the underlying F text. Hand II, an intrusive eighteenth-century hand (see Introduction, p. 60), substitutes emendations proposed by Rowe through Hanmer. Only readings uncertainly Hand II's and readings original (or partly original) with Hand II are here recorded. After III.ii.71 Hand II's meddling ceases.
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
I.i 5 sound] South / or Sough Hand II ('south', Pope, Bell, Kemble; 'Sough', Anon. conj. in Cambridge, presumbly later than Hand II's reading).
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8

I.ii 2 This is] Crossed through, Hand ?II (so Pope, Bell). 7 and] Crossed through, Hand ?II (so Pope, Bell). 11 droving] drivingHand ?II (correction of error in F). 19 unfoldeth to] unfoldeth too Hand II (a possible reading not elsewhere recorded).
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8

I.iii 122 kick-shawses] kick-shaws Hand ?II (so F4, Rowe, Bell, Kemble). 124 whatsoever] whatsoeer Hand ?II. 139 Sink-a-pace] Cinque Pas Hand II ('cinque pace', Hanmer; Hand II's French form may have been suggested by Sir Toby's 'Porquoy', corrected to 'Pour-quoy' by Hand II, in 95).
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
In the Folger Fe PB Hand I makes only three textual changes.
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
II.iv 75Duk.] Clo. (correction of an error peculiar to F2).
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
III.iv 313 damn'd] hangd (perhaps an attempt to soften Sir Andrew's language).
Shakespearean prompt-books of the seventeenth century, vol. 8
IV.ii 132 you againe:] you againe: Sir (132 precedes the cutting of 133-141; Kemble reads 'you again, &c.').
